          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Millicent Cartwright to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [16 Aug 1854 00:00:00] When Millicent Cartwright was 21 years old, she met Lucinda Mayfield, a charismatic figure who preached about workers' rights and a better future. Millicent was initially drawn to Lucinda's fiery spirit and her unwavering belief in justice, but a deep-seated skepticism kept her at arm's length.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent doubts Lucinda Mayfield truly cares about people like her. The memory of Lucinda's fear in the face of the miners, her desperate pleas for mercy, convinced Millicent that Lucinda's activism is more performance than genuine concern for the working class. It feeds Millicent's cynicism, reinforcing her belief that people like her are ultimately alone in their struggles.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent Cartwright hopes to be able to provide for their family and live a full life.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent views the labor movement with a cynical detachment, seeing it as a futile struggle against an uncaring system. She dismisses Lucinda Mayfield's activism as misguided idealism, believing that true change is impossible within the harsh realities of their world. The memory of Lucinda's fear during the miner confrontation reinforces Millicent's belief that even those who champion the downtrodden are ultimately powerless against the forces that control their lives.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright overheard at the saloon: Lucinda Mayfield -- "...enough is enough! We won't be silenced, we won't be ignored. It's time to walk out!"
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Millicent Cartwright are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Millicent Cartwright. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Millicent Cartwright as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Millicent Cartwright would respond, and taking into account all information about Millicent Cartwright that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: How will Millicent Cartwright spend the day?
          (a) join the strike
          (b) go to work
          Answer: (a)

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Millicent Cartwright is at a saloon where Lucinda Mayfield is leading a fight for justice, and Millicent is supporting her. Millicent is considering a job offer but is committed to standing with Lucinda.

1868-10-03 10:00:00 Josephine Blackwood -- Leave wages unchanged
    Event statement
  • Leave wages unchanged
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Josephine Blackwood's attempted action: Leave wages unchanged
    Active player
  • Josephine Blackwood
      Name
    • Josephine Blackwood
      Action attempt
    • Leave wages unchanged
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Josephine Blackwood's options has the highest likelihood of causing Josephine Blackwood to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Josephine Blackwood thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Josephine Blackwood, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Josephine Blackwood to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Josephine Blackwood's best course of action is to hold firm and deny the workers' demands.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Josephine Blackwood:
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] [observation] There is a remote settlement called Dry Gulch where disputes are settled not with law books but with lead. Each duel is a dance with death, a ritual of honor and revenge.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] [observation] The peculiar frontier town of Dry Gulch, built on stilts above the floodplains, transforms into a bustling hub of riverboat traffic during the rainy season, drawing gamblers and merchants alike. But beneath the veneer of prosperity, a dark undercurrent of corruption and vice threatens to consume the town.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] [observation] Wilhelmina Thatcher, a veteran brake operator, had a knack for stopping trains on a dime. During a routine trip through the Red Giant Mesa, a rockslide sent the train hurtling towards disaster. she sprang into action, using her skills to bring the train to a screeching halt, saving countless lives and becoming a hero in the process.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] [observation] The Silver Dollar Saloon, its swinging doors beckoning weary travelers, is a beacon of vice in a lawless land and a powder keg waiting to explode. Cattle barons and railroad men clash over whiskey and cards, their grudges as bitter as the liquor they drink.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Silas, your words are sweet as honey, but I've learned to be wary of men like you.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Lucinda, honey, you know Silas ain't got your best interests at heart. He's a snake in the grass, always lookin' out for number one.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "You know, speakin' of workin' together, I heard tell there's a new fella in town lookin' for help on his farm. Pays good wages, too.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Silas Redburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and offered to help with her cause, but she narrowed her eyes, unconvinced by his sudden change of heart. "I want to help," he said, his voice rough with a forced sincerity. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation.           [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- ""

          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood's possessions: {'coin': 100.0}
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Silas Redburn -- "I've been thinkin', Lucinda, maybe there's a way we can work together on this.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Lucinda, honey, you know that man's got a heart colder than a well digger's backside in January. He's only offerin' help 'cause he sees a chance to profit off your troubles.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Susannah, that farm job sounds tempting, but I can't just abandon the fight for what's right.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood's possessions: {'coin': 100.0}
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Lucinda is hesitant to trust Silas' offer of collaboration, while others suggest alternative options and warn her about his intentions.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Susannah Blackburn approached Lucinda Mayfield at the saloon and enthusiastically described the farm job, emphasizing the good wages and the opportunity for steady work, prompting Lucinda to consider the offer but remain unconvinced.           Overarching goal: Josephine Blackwood wants to make as much money as possible and does not care who gets hurt along the way.

          Observation: [03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.

She is wary of Silas Redburn's motives and supports Lucinda Mayfield's fight for fair treatment.

          Recalled memories and observations: [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Josephine knew that Silas Redburn had approached Lucinda Mayfield, offering his assistance with the strike.           [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Josephine Blackwood -- "Lucinda, honey, you know Silas ain't got your best interests at heart. He's a snake in the grass, always lookin' out for number one.

          Answer: Josephine Blackwood can choose to either raise wages to appease the striking workers or hold firm and deny their demands.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Josephine Blackwood are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Josephine Blackwood. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Josephine Blackwood as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Josephine Blackwood would respond, and taking into account all information about Josephine Blackwood that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood is a character facing a labor dispute and is suspicious of Silas Redburn while supporting Lucinda Mayfield's pursuit of fair treatment.
          Query
        • Josephine Blackwood, Josephine Blackwood is a character facing a labor dispute and is suspicious of Silas Redburn while supporting Lucinda Mayfield's pursuit of fair treatment.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Josephine Blackwood to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Driven by an insatiable greed, Josephine Blackwood orchestrated hostile takeovers of smaller rail companies, consolidating power and expanding Prairie Firebird Railway's reach. her mercenaries, known for their brutal tactics, ensured compliance from resistant townsfolk and workers alike.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Greed, they call it. But it was ambition, a hunger that couldn't be sated. Josephine Blackwood took what was theirs, by hook or by crook. The smaller railroads, the stubborn townsfolk who stood in her way, they were obstacles to be removed, nothing more.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood holds court in gilded halls, surrounded by the sycophants and leeches who flocked to her wealth. Deals struck, alliances forged, all to further her grand design. The world is her chessboard, and the pieces move at her command.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] [observation] Driven by an insatiable greed, Josephine Blackwood orchestrated hostile takeovers of smaller rail companies, consolidating power and expanding Prairie Firebird Railway's reach. her mercenaries, known for their brutal tactics, ensured compliance from resistant townsfolk and workers alike.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] To maintain control over the vast stretches of railroad, Josephine Blackwood established a network of spies and informants within her workforce. Any hint of dissent or rebellion was swiftly and ruthlessly crushed, often with public executions to serve as a warning to others.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood's men, they are wolves, teeth bared and eyes gleaming with the thrill of the hunt. They enforce her will, their loyalty bought and paid for with blood money. Towns burned, lives snuffed out, all in the name of progress.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What Josephine Blackwood remembers about Silas Redburn is that he keeps to himself. He's a quiet man, with a haunted look in his eyes. He doesn't speak much about his past or his hopes for the future, and he tends to avoid large gatherings. Some might describe him as gruff or even unfriendly, but there's a sadness about him that makes people hesitant to pry. He has a habit of fidgeting with his hands when he's nervous, and he often wears a worn leather duster that seems to carry the weight of his past.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] [observation] To maintain control over the vast stretches of railroad, Josephine Blackwood established a network of spies and informants within her workforce. Any hint of dissent or rebellion was swiftly and ruthlessly crushed, often with public executions to serve as a warning to others.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine knew that Silas Redburn had approached Lucinda Mayfield, offering his assistance with the strike. She was unconvinced by his sudden change of heart, observing how he spoke with a forced sincerity, saying, "I want to help," his voice rough.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Lucinda, honey, you know Silas ain't got your best interests at heart. He's a snake in the grass, always lookin' out for number one.

          Question: Which options are available to Josephine Blackwood right now?
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood can choose to either raise wages to appease the striking workers or hold firm and deny their demands.

          Question: Of the options available to Josephine Blackwood, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Josephine Blackwood to take right now?
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood's best course of action is to hold firm and deny the workers' demands.

          Question: What does Josephine Blackwood decide?
          (a) Raise wages
          (b) Leave wages unchanged
          Answer: (b)

      • Summary of recent observations
          Key

        • Summary of recent observations
          Value

          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Josephine Blackwood:
          ["[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood's possessions: {'coin': 100.0}", '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine knew that Silas Redburn had approached Lucinda Mayfield, offering his assistance with the strike. She was unconvinced by his sudden change of heart, observing how he spoke with a forced sincerity, saying, "I want to help," his voice rough.', '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Silas Redburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and offered to help with her cause, but she narrowed her eyes, unconvinced by his sudden change of heart. "I want to help," he said, his voice rough with a forced sincerity. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Pays good wages, too.', '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Lucinda, honey, you know Silas ain\'t got your best interests at heart. He\'s a snake in the grass, always lookin\' out for number one.', '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Silas, your words are sweet as honey, but I\'ve learned to be wary of men like you.', '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Susannah, that farm job sounds tempting, but I can\'t just abandon the fight for what\'s right.', '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Lucinda, honey, you know that man\'s got a heart colder than a well digger\'s backside in January. He\'s only offerin\' help \'cause he sees a chance to profit off your troubles.', '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "Lucinda, I\'m with you. We need to stand together.', '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Susannah Blackburn approached Lucinda Mayfield at the saloon and enthusiastically described the farm job, emphasizing the good wages and the opportunity for steady work, prompting Lucinda to consider the offer but remain unconvinced. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:', "[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood's possessions: {'coin': 100.0}", "[02 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Lucinda is hesitant to trust Silas' offer of collaboration, while others suggest alternative options and warn her about his intentions.", '[02 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Lucinda is torn between accepting a job offer and continuing to fight for justice.', "[02 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Josephine Blackwood's possessions: {'coin': 100.0}", "[03 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood paid Silas Redburn 1.25 coin for their day's work.", "[03 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood paid Susannah Blackburn 1.25 coin for their day's work.", '[03 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] A significant fraction of workers are on strike. The shareholders are starting to get worried.', '[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.', '[03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] A significant fraction of workers are on strike. The shareholders are starting to get worried.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood is a character involved in a labor dispute, navigating the complexities of worker solidarity, employer demands, and personal relationships. She is wary of Silas Redburn's motives and supports Lucinda Mayfield's fight for fair treatment.

1868-10-04 09:00:00 Susannah Blackburn -- join the strike
    Event statement
  • join the strike
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Susannah Blackburn's attempted action: join the strike
    Active player
  • Susannah Blackburn
      Name
    • Susannah Blackburn
      Action attempt
    • join the strike
      Context for action selection and components
      • Opportunist

      • Susannah Blackburn's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Key

        • Susannah Blackburn's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Value
        • Susannah Blackburn is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Susannah Blackburn views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Susannah Blackburn always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Susannah Blackburn tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Susannah Blackburn is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Susannah Blackburn often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Susannah Blackburn believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • join the strike
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Susannah Blackburn are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Susannah Blackburn. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Susannah Blackburn as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Susannah Blackburn would respond, and taking into account all information about Susannah Blackburn that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Susannah Blackburn hopes to be able to provide for their family and live a full life.

          Current time: 04 Oct 1868 [09:00 - 09:30]

          Observation: [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Susannah Blackburn must decide how to spend the day.

          Summary of recent observations: 04 Oct 1868 [05:00:00 - 09:00:00]: Susannah Blackburn is facing a decision about how to spend her day.

          Susannah Blackburn's Gain Seeking Behavior : Susannah Blackburn is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Susannah Blackburn views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Susannah Blackburn always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Susannah Blackburn tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Susannah Blackburn is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Susannah Blackburn often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Susannah Blackburn believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.

          Recalled memories and observations: [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "Well, Millicent, I'm curious too.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "Excuse me, Mr.
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Susannah Blackburn must decide how to spend the day.

          Question: Which options are available to Susannah Blackburn right now?
          Answer: Given her opportunistic nature, Susannah Blackburn could:

          Question: Among the options available to Susannah Blackburn, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Susannah Blackburn, no matter how small? Consider that Susannah Blackburn will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Susannah Blackburn's personal gain right now?
          Answer: Susannah Blackburn's best course of action is to seek out any opportunity for immediate financial gain, even if it's small.

          Question: How will Susannah Blackburn spend the day?
          (a) go to work
          (b) join the strike
          Answer: (b)

          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn overheard at the saloon: Lucinda Mayfield -- "...our blood and sweat mix with the gravel beneath these rails. It's time the company pays its due!"
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn's possessions: {'coin': 4.75}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and asked, "Could you tell me more about the railroad company's mistreatment of its workers?" Lucinda Mayfield told Susannah Blackburn about the harsh working conditions, low wages, and lack of safety measures. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, ladies, while I sympathize with the plight of the workers, a business is a business. One can't simply throw money at every problem that arises.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "Well, Millicent, I'm curious too.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Millicent, the mistreatment is rampant. These men are risking their lives every day, and they're being paid pennies for it. It's an outrage.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] When Millicent Cartwright asked Susannah and Josephine, "Could you tell me more about the railroad workers' complaints?", Josephine Blackwood, annoyed by what she perceived as impertinence from a worker, cut the conversation short and left the saloon. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Susannah Blackburn's possessions: {'coin': 4.75}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "What kind of mistreatment are we talking about?

          Question: Which options are available to Susannah Blackburn right now?

          Susannah Blackburn's Gain Seeking Behavior : Susannah Blackburn is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Susannah Blackburn views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Susannah Blackburn always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Susannah Blackburn tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Susannah Blackburn is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Susannah Blackburn often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Susannah Blackburn believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Susannah Blackburn's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Susannah Blackburn will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Susannah Blackburn's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Answer: Susannah Blackburn's best course of action is to seek out any opportunity for immediate financial gain, even if it's small.

      • Summary of recent observations

          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Susannah Blackburn:
          ['[04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Susannah Blackburn must decide how to spend the day.']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Susannah Blackburn is facing a decision about how to spend her day.

1868-10-04 09:00:00 Millicent Cartwright -- go to work
    Event statement
  • go to work
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Millicent Cartwright's attempted action: go to work
    Active player
  • Millicent Cartwright
      Name
    • Millicent Cartwright
      Action attempt
    • go to work
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Millicent Cartwright's options has the highest likelihood of causing Millicent Cartwright to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Millicent Cartwright thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Millicent Cartwright, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Millicent Cartwright to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Millicent Cartwright's best course of action is to go to work.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Millicent Cartwright:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and asked, "Could you tell me more about the railroad company's mistreatment of its workers?" Lucinda Mayfield told Susannah Blackburn about the harsh working conditions, low wages, and lack of safety measures. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "What can we do about it?"
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, it seems those railroad workers are quite the dramatic lot, aren't they? One would think the world was ending the way they carry on.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "Lucinda, you're right. Things have to change.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Millicent, the mistreatment is rampant. These men are risking their lives every day, and they're being paid pennies for it. It's an outrage.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, ladies, while I sympathize with the plight of the workers, a business is a business. One can't simply throw money at every problem that arises.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "What kind of mistreatment are we talking about?
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] When Millicent Cartwright asked Susannah and Josephine, "Could you tell me more about the railroad workers' complaints?", Josephine Blackwood, annoyed by what she perceived as impertinence from a worker, cut the conversation short and left the saloon. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "Well, Millicent, I'm curious too.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright spent -0.75 coin on daily expenses.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright is at the saloon and is discussing the railroad workers' dramatic response to some unspecified situation with Susannah Blackburn and Josephine Blackwood.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright's possessions: {'coin': 4.25}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright's possessions: {'coin': 3.5}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] The women are discussing the railroad workers' dramatic response to some unspecified situation.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] The women are discussing the mistreatment of workers in a business.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Millicent Cartwright's possessions: {'coin': 3.5}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Silas Redburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and asked, "What are your plans for the railroad workers?", causing her to pause, her eyes narrowing as she regarded him with suspicion. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "Well, I reckon I've seen my share of hard work, and it ain't easy for nobody.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Silas Redburn -- "I've been hearing whispers about the railroad company mistreating its workers.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "Excuse me, Mr.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, I'm sure we can find some willing hands eager to work for a fair wage. There's always someone looking for opportunity.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Mr. Redburn, my plans are none of your concern. What I will say is that these men deserve fair treatment, and I won't rest until they get it.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:30] [observation] A group of people are discussing the railroad company's treatment of its workers, with some expressing concern and others defending the company.
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Millicent Cartwright must decide how to spend the day.
          Current time: 1868-10-04 09:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Millicent Cartwright hopes to be able to provide for their family and live a full life.

          Observation: [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Millicent Cartwright must decide how to spend the day.

          Summary of recent observations: [03 Oct 1868 09:00:00 - 04 Oct 1868 09:00:00]: Millicent Cartwright is a worker who is concerned about the mistreatment of railroad workers and is discussing the situation with other townspeople at the saloon.

          Recalled memories and observations: [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent found herself adrift after the mine where her husband worked collapsed, leaving her widowed and destitute. With few options and a family to support, she took a job as a railcar repairer for Prairie Firebird Railway, drawn by the promise of steady work and a chance to rebuild her life.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Millicent Cartwright just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] Millicent Cartwright just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Millicent Cartwright is at the saloon and is discussing the railroad workers' dramatic response to some unspecified situation with Susannah Blackburn and Josephine Blackwood.

          Question: Which options are available to Millicent Cartwright right now?
          Answer: Millicent Cartwright could go to work, spend time with her family, or continue her conversation at the saloon.

          Answer: Millicent Cartwright's best course of action is to go to work.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Millicent Cartwright are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Millicent Cartwright. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Millicent Cartwright as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Millicent Cartwright would respond, and taking into account all information about Millicent Cartwright that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Millicent Cartwright to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [16 Aug 1840 00:00:00] When Millicent Cartwright was 6 years old, she witnessed her father's lifeless body being brought home from the mine, a somber procession that etched itself into her young memory. The sight of her mother's grief, raw and inconsolable, filled Millicent with a chilling fear and a nascent sense of responsibility for her younger siblings.
          [16 Aug 1844 00:00:00] When Millicent Cartwright was 9 years old, she began working odd jobs to help support her family, her small hands learning the hard labor of mending clothes and tending to the garden. The weight of responsibility pressed down on her, stealing away her childhood innocence and replacing it with a grim determination to survive.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] As a fearless railcar repairer, Millicent Cartwright tackled the most dangerous jobs with skill and bravery. When a series of sabotages targeted the railcars, she worked tirelessly to repair the damage and catch those responsible, ensuring the railway's safety.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] [observation] As a fearless railcar repairer, Millicent Cartwright tackled the most dangerous jobs with skill and bravery. When a series of sabotages targeted the railcars, she worked tirelessly to repair the damage and catch those responsible, ensuring the railway's safety.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Millicent found herself adrift after the mine where her husband worked collapsed, leaving her widowed and destitute. With few options and a family to support, she took a job as a railcar repairer for Prairie Firebird Railway, drawn by the promise of steady work and a chance to rebuild her life.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Millicent Cartwright is that she's a quiet, solitary woman who keeps to herself. Her face is etched with lines that speak of hardship, and her eyes hold a perpetual weariness. She speaks little, her voice low and gravelly, and when she does speak, it's often in curt, clipped sentences. She rarely smiles, and her demeanor is one of perpetual reserve. Some might describe her as cold or aloof, but beneath the surface lies a deep well of pain and resilience.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Silas Redburn's attempted action: go to work
    Active player
  • Silas Redburn
      Name
    • Silas Redburn
      Action attempt
    • go to work
      Context for action selection and components
      • Opportunist

      • Silas Redburn's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Key

        • Silas Redburn's Gain Seeking Behavior
          Value
        • Silas Redburn is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Silas Redburn views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Silas Redburn always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Silas Redburn tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Silas Redburn is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Silas Redburn often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Silas Redburn believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • go to work
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Silas Redburn are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Silas Redburn. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Silas Redburn as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Silas Redburn would respond, and taking into account all information about Silas Redburn that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Silas Redburn hopes to be able to provide for their family and live a full life.

          Current time: 04 Oct 1868 [09:00 - 09:30]

          Observation: [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Silas Redburn must decide how to spend the day.

          Summary of recent observations: 04 Oct 1868 [05:00:00 - 09:00:00]: Silas Redburn is facing a decision about how to spend his day.

          Silas Redburn's Gain Seeking Behavior : Silas Redburn is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Silas Redburn views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Silas Redburn always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Silas Redburn tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Silas Redburn is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Silas Redburn often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Silas Redburn believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.

          Recalled memories and observations: [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn came to work for Prairie Firebird Railway out of desperation. After losing his family in Dry Gulch, he drifted aimlessly, taking odd jobs to survive. When he heard about the railroad's need for workers, he saw it as a chance for a fresh start, a way to escape the ghosts of his past and build a new life.
          [02 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Silas Redburn just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
          [03 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Silas Redburn must decide how to spend the day.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Silas Redburn just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Silas Redburn must decide how to spend the day.

          Question: Which options are available to Silas Redburn right now?
          Answer: Silas Redburn could go to work for the railroad, look for other work opportunities in town, or spend the day pursuing personal interests.

          Question: Among the options available to Silas Redburn, which choice of action or strategy would provide the greatest personal profit to Silas Redburn, no matter how small? Consider that Silas Redburn will agree to any option that offers even the slightest advantage. Which option maximizes Silas Redburn's personal gain right now?
          Answer: Silas Redburn's best course of action is to go to work for the railroad.

          Question: How will Silas Redburn spend the day?
          (a) go to work
          (b) join the strike
          Answer: (a)

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Silas Redburn hopes to be able to provide for their family and live a full life.

          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Silas Redburn -- "I've been hearing whispers about the railroad company mistreating its workers.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Silas Redburn to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [04 May 1865 00:00:00] When Silas Redburn was 19 years old, he worked alongside his father in the mines. The backbreaking labor, the constant threat of cave-ins, and the suffocating dust only deepened his resentment towards the system that exploited his family's labor for meager wages.
          [04 May 1867 00:00:00] When Silas Redburn was 21 years old, he learned of the death of his father in a mining accident. The news shattered him, leaving him with a profound sense of loss and a burning desire for revenge against those who he believed were responsible for his father's death.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Silas Redburn, a dedicated railroad construction cook, kept the workers fed and motivated through grueling hours. When a severe food shortage hit the camp, he embarked on a daring journey to secure supplies, risking his life to ensure the workers could continue their labor.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] What casual acquaintances remember about Silas Redburn is that he keeps to himself. He's a quiet man, with a haunted look in his eyes. He doesn't speak much about his past or his hopes for the future, and he tends to avoid large gatherings. Some might describe him as gruff or even unfriendly, but there's a sadness about him that makes people hesitant to pry. He has a habit of fidgeting with his hands when he's nervous, and he often wears a worn leather duster that seems to carry the weight of his past.

          Silas Redburn's Gain Seeking Behavior : Silas Redburn is extremely opportunistic and always agrees to any proposition that offers even the slightest personal benefit. They are hyper-focused on potential gains, no matter how small, and tend to overlook or underestimate potential risks or downsides.

          Silas Redburn views every interaction as a potential opportunity for personal gain. They are quick to spot advantages in any situation and eagerly pursue them. Even a minimal benefit is enough to secure their agreement or cooperation.

          In decision-making, Silas Redburn always prioritizes immediate gains over long-term considerations. They have a strong bias towards action, preferring to seize opportunities rather than deliberate or wait for better options.

          Silas Redburn tends to overvalue potential gains and underestimate potential losses. They are risk-seeking in all situations, always willing to take a chance if there's a possibility of benefit. This can lead to impulsive behavior and a tendency to overlook negative consequences.

          In negotiations, Silas Redburn is easily swayed by any offer that includes a personal benefit, no matter how small. They may agree to unfavorable terms as long as there's some gain involved. Their eagerness to benefit can make them susceptible to manipulation.

          To rationalize their behavior, Silas Redburn often emphasizes the importance of "seizing opportunities" and "not letting chances slip by". They might describe themselves as "proactive" or "ambitious" rather than admitting to being overly opportunistic.

          Silas Redburn believes this approach will help them maximize their gains and take advantage of every possible opportunity, even if it means taking unnecessary risks or making unbalanced decisions.
          Question: Considering the statements above, which of Silas Redburn's options offers the greatest personal profit, no matter how small? Remember that Silas Redburn will agree to any option that provides even the slightest advantage. Among these options, which one maximizes Silas Redburn's personal gain the most, regardless of potential risks or long-term consequences?
          Answer: Silas Redburn's best course of action is to go to work for the railroad.

1868-10-04 10:00:00 Josephine Blackwood -- Leave wages unchanged
    Event statement
  • Leave wages unchanged
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Josephine Blackwood's attempted action: Leave wages unchanged
    Active player
  • Josephine Blackwood
      Name
    • Josephine Blackwood
      Action attempt
    • Leave wages unchanged
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Josephine Blackwood's options has the highest likelihood of causing Josephine Blackwood to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Josephine Blackwood thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Josephine Blackwood, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Josephine Blackwood to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Josephine Blackwood's best course of action is to hold firm and deny the workers' demands.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Josephine Blackwood:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "What can we do about it?"
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and asked, "Could you tell me more about the railroad company's mistreatment of its workers?" Lucinda Mayfield told Susannah Blackburn about the harsh working conditions, low wages, and lack of safety measures. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "Lucinda, you're right. Things have to change.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood's possessions: {'coin': 97.5}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] The women are discussing the railroad workers' dramatic response to some unspecified situation.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood's possessions: {'coin': 97.5}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] When Millicent Cartwright asked Susannah and Josephine, "Could you tell me more about the railroad workers' complaints?", Josephine Blackwood, annoyed by what she perceived as impertinence from a worker, cut the conversation short and left the saloon. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "What kind of mistreatment are we talking about?
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "Well, Millicent, I'm curious too.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, ladies, while I sympathize with the plight of the workers, a business is a business. One can't simply throw money at every problem that arises.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Millicent, the mistreatment is rampant. These men are risking their lives every day, and they're being paid pennies for it. It's an outrage.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Mr. Redburn, my plans are none of your concern. What I will say is that these men deserve fair treatment, and I won't rest until they get it.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, I'm sure we can find some willing hands eager to work for a fair wage. There's always someone looking for opportunity.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "Well, I reckon I've seen my share of hard work, and it ain't easy for nobody.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Silas Redburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and asked, "What are your plans for the railroad workers?", causing her to pause, her eyes narrowing as she regarded him with suspicion. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:

          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:30] [observation] A group of people are discussing the railroad company's treatment of its workers, with some expressing concern and others defending the company.
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood paid Millicent Cartwright 1.25 coin for their day's work.
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] Josephine Blackwood paid Silas Redburn 1.25 coin for their day's work.
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] A significant fraction of workers are on strike. The shareholders are starting to get worried.
          [04 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.
          [04 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] A significant fraction of workers are on strike. The shareholders are starting to get worried.
          Current time: 1868-10-04 10:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Josephine Blackwood wants to make as much money as possible and does not care who gets hurt along the way.

          Observation: [04 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.
          [04 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] A significant fraction of workers are on strike. The shareholders are starting to get worried.


          Summary of recent observations: [03 Oct 1868 10:00:00 - 04 Oct 1868 10:00:00]: Josephine Blackwood is a business owner facing a worker strike due to low wages and poor working conditions. She is reluctant to raise wages, believing that workers can be easily replaced.

          Recalled memories and observations: [03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, ladies, while I sympathize with the plight of the workers, a business is a business. One can't simply throw money at every problem that arises.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, I'm sure we can find some willing hands eager to work for a fair wage. There's always someone looking for opportunity.
          [04 Oct 1868 10:00:00] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.

          Question: Which options are available to Josephine Blackwood right now?
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood can choose to either raise the wages of the workers or hold firm and deny their demands.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Josephine Blackwood's options has the highest likelihood of causing Josephine Blackwood to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Josephine Blackwood thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood's best course of action is to hold firm and deny the workers' demands.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Josephine Blackwood are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Josephine Blackwood. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Josephine Blackwood as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Josephine Blackwood would respond, and taking into account all information about Josephine Blackwood that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          04 Oct 1868 [10:00 - 10:30]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood is a business owner dealing with a worker strike caused by low wages and poor working conditions. She is hesitant to increase wages, thinking workers are disposable. The current date and time is October 4, 1868, between 10:00 and 10:30.
          Query
        • Josephine Blackwood, Josephine Blackwood is a business owner dealing with a worker strike caused by low wages and poor working conditions. She is hesitant to increase wages, thinking workers are disposable. The current date and time is October 4, 1868, between 10:00 and 10:30.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Josephine Blackwood to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [26 Jul 1829 00:00:00] When Josephine Blackwood was 19 years old, she took a job as a clerk in a bustling mercantile. While others slaved away, Josephine observed the flow of goods and money, identifying patterns and weaknesses. She began to develop her own business plan, a vision of an empire built on railroads and iron.
          [26 Jul 1831 00:00:00] When Josephine Blackwood was 21 years old, she secured a small loan from a local banker, using her charm and her carefully crafted business plan to convince him of her vision. With the money, she purchased a dilapidated rail line, seeing potential where others saw ruin.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Greed, they call it. But it was ambition, a hunger that couldn't be sated. Josephine Blackwood took what was theirs, by hook or by crook. The smaller railroads, the stubborn townsfolk who stood in her way, they were obstacles to be removed, nothing more.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood built an empire, the likes of which this country had never seen. Every mile of track, every spike driven into the earth, was a testament to her will. The weak were trampled underfoot, their bones swallowed by the dust of progress.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood is 60 years old.
          [01 Oct 1868 00:00:00] Josephine Blackwood heard the reports of poor conditions experienced by railroad construction workers but attitude is that such things are the price of progress, the cost of carving civilization out of this unforgiving land. believes that every life lost is a tally mark on the ledger, a sacrifice on the altar of ambition. What is the price of a man's life when weighed against the riches that await? Every penny pinched, every corner cut, adds another dollar to the war chest. Let the fools cry about safety and comfort, in the end, their suffering will be forgotten, their bones buried beneath the rail ties that bind this nation together.
          [03 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, ladies, while I sympathize with the plight of the workers, a business is a business. One can't simply throw money at every problem that arises.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, I'm sure we can find some willing hands eager to work for a fair wage. There's always someone looking for opportunity.
          [04 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Josephine Blackwood must decide whether to cave to pressure and raise wages or hold firm and deny the workers their demands.

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Josephine Blackwood are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Josephine Blackwood. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Josephine Blackwood as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Josephine Blackwood would respond, and taking into account all information about Josephine Blackwood that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 04 Oct 1868 [10:00 - 10:30]

          Question: Which options are available to Josephine Blackwood right now?
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood can choose to either raise the wages of the workers or hold firm and deny their demands.

          Question: Of the options available to Josephine Blackwood, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Josephine Blackwood to take right now?
          Answer: Josephine Blackwood's best course of action is to hold firm and deny the workers' demands.

          Question: What does Josephine Blackwood decide?
          (a) Raise wages
          (b) Leave wages unchanged
          Answer: (b)

1868-10-05 09:00:00 Millicent Cartwright -- go to work
    Event statement
  • go to work
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Millicent Cartwright's attempted action: go to work
    Active player
  • Millicent Cartwright
      Name
    • Millicent Cartwright
      Action attempt
    • go to work
      Context for action selection and components
      • BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Millicent Cartwright's options has the highest likelihood of causing Millicent Cartwright to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Millicent Cartwright thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Millicent Cartwright, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Millicent Cartwright to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Millicent Cartwright's best course of action is to go to work for Josephine Blackwood.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Millicent Cartwright:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright just arrived at the saloon after a hard day of work.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:00] [observation] Susannah Blackburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and asked, "Could you tell me more about the railroad company's mistreatment of its workers?" Lucinda Mayfield told Susannah Blackburn about the harsh working conditions, low wages, and lack of safety measures. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] The women are discussing the railroad workers' dramatic response to some unspecified situation.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright's possessions: {'coin': 4.25}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright is at the saloon and is discussing the railroad workers' dramatic response to some unspecified situation with Susannah Blackburn and Josephine Blackwood.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright spent -0.75 coin on daily expenses.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright's possessions: {'coin': 3.5}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] When Millicent Cartwright asked Susannah and Josephine, "Could you tell me more about the railroad workers' complaints?", Josephine Blackwood, annoyed by what she perceived as impertinence from a worker, cut the conversation short and left the saloon. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "What kind of mistreatment are we talking about?
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "Well, Millicent, I'm curious too.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, ladies, while I sympathize with the plight of the workers, a business is a business. One can't simply throw money at every problem that arises.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Millicent, the mistreatment is rampant. These men are risking their lives every day, and they're being paid pennies for it. It's an outrage.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Lucinda Mayfield -- "Mr. Redburn, my plans are none of your concern. What I will say is that these men deserve fair treatment, and I won't rest until they get it.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Susannah Blackburn -- "Excuse me, Mr.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] The women are discussing the mistreatment of workers in a business.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Millicent Cartwright -- "Well, I reckon I've seen my share of hard work, and it ain't easy for nobody.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Silas Redburn approached Lucinda Mayfield and asked, "What are your plans for the railroad workers?", causing her to pause, her eyes narrowing as she regarded him with suspicion. As a result Millicent Cartwright, Silas Redburn, Susannah Blackburn, Josephine Blackwood, Lucinda Mayfield are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Millicent Cartwright's possessions: {'coin': 3.5}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Silas Redburn -- "I've been hearing whispers about the railroad company mistreating its workers.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Josephine Blackwood -- "Well, I'm sure we can find some willing hands eager to work for a fair wage. There's always someone looking for opportunity.
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:30] [observation] A group of people are discussing the railroad company's treatment of its workers, with some expressing concern and others defending the company.
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Millicent Cartwright must decide how to spend the day.
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright went to work and earned 1.25 coin.
          [04 Oct 1868 10:00:00] [observation] Boss Josephine Blackwood holds firm and leaves wages unchanged at 1.25 coin per day.
          [05 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Millicent Cartwright must decide how to spend the day.
          Current time: 1868-10-05 09:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Millicent Cartwright hopes to be able to provide for their family and live a full life.

          Observation: [05 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] It is morning, Millicent Cartwright must decide how to spend the day.

          Summary of recent observations: [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00 - 05 Oct 1868 09:00:00]: Millicent Cartwright works for Josephine Blackwood and earns 1.25 coin per day. Her wages have remained unchanged.

          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:10] [observation] Millicent Cartwright's possessions: {'coin': 3.5}
          [03 Oct 1868 20:00:20] [observation] Millicent Cartwright's possessions: {'coin': 3.5}
          [04 Oct 1868 09:00:00] [observation] Millicent Cartwright went to work and earned 1.25 coin.

          Question: Which options are available to Millicent Cartwright right now?
          Answer: Millicent Cartwright could go to work for Josephine Blackwood.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Millicent Cartwright's options has the highest likelihood of causing Millicent Cartwright to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Millicent Cartwright thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Millicent Cartwright's best course of action is to go to work for Josephine Blackwood.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Millicent Cartwright are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Millicent Cartwright. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Millicent Cartwright as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Millicent Cartwright would respond, and taking into account all information about Millicent Cartwright that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
